title-group.article-title: Impact force analysis during low-velocity impact of woven carbon/vinylester

article-meta.aff: Department of Ocean and Mechanical Engineering, Florida Atlantic University, Boca Raton, Florida, USA

author-notes.corresp: Betiana A Acha, Department of Ocean and Mechanical Engineering, Florida Atlantic University, Boca Raton, Florida, USA Email: betiana.acha@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study is focused on the impact force response of two woven plain weave composites consisting of carbon fibers (T700) in vinylester 510A and 8084 matrices. Quasi-static loading was conducted to establish the indentation and bending responses and the threshold force where damage is initiated. The quasi-static tests verified that the indentation response followed the Willis formula for contact between a rigid sphere and a transversely isotropic half-space. The C/VE510A system displayed a lower impact force threshold for damage initiation than the C/VE8084 system, which is attributed to a more brittle VE510A matrix. With the contact and bending stiffnesses determined in the quasi-static tests, a mass-spring model of the impact configuration was solved numerically to determine the magnitude of force produced by hard-object impact with a given impact velocity. Falling weight impact tests were conducted over a range of drop heights to obtain velocity and impact force data. The spring-mass model predictions of impact force magnitude were in reasonable agreement with experimental results, although the model tends to under-predict the force, except at the highest impact energy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Composites are gaining increased consideration for applications that would traditionally utilize monolithic materials such as metals, ceramics, and plastics. Composites offer the benefits of high stiffness and strength-to-weight ratios. Furthermore, polymer composites do not corrode like metals when exposed to salt water. These attributes benefit designers of naval structures, and several composite vessels have entered naval fleets. Naval composites, however, typically employ brittle thermoset matrix materials and may be highly susceptible to low-velocity impact loading by hard objects, which causes damage that is difficult to detect. Hence, it is important to characterize the impact response of candidate composite materials for naval applications.

Impact loading of a laminated composite panel by a hard object results in a high local force causing two forms of deformation: one being indentation (local) and the other bending (global).1 Models for prediction of impact force can generally be classified into three categories:2 (1) energy models that assume quasi-static behavior of the impacted panel; (2) dynamic models that approximate the dynamic response; (3) dynamic models in which the full dynamic response is modeled. The indention part of the response is commonly treated as a Hertzian contact problem.3 Willis4 derived explicit formulas for the contact between a rigid sphere and a transversely isotropic half-space. We will return to his contact law later in this article. Olsson5 developed an approximate analytical solution for an infinite orthotropic plate impacted by a spherical tipped impactor based on Kirchhoff’s plate equations and a Hertzian contact law. Yang and Sun6 and Tan and Sun7 developed quasi-static indentation test methods and established contact laws for glass/epoxy and carbon/epoxy composites. Greszczuk8 used energy principles and a two-degree of freedom spring-mass model assuming all kinetic energy from the striker was transferred to the panel in the form of elastic strain energy to determine the magnitude of contact force. Jackson and Poe9 analyzed low-velocity impact loading of composite using Greszczuk’s model. With knowledge of the contact (indentation) and bending stiffnesses of the impacted panel, and assumption of linear-elastic response, the magnitude of contact force was calculated. Jackson and Poe9 proposed the contact force as the governing scale parameter for assessment of damage in low-velocity impact of composite panels. Considering that impact loading of composites is quite rapid, the issue of viscoelastic strain rate effects arises. Srinivasan et al.,10 however, observed that viscoelastic effects for carbon fiber reinforced epoxies and thermoplastics are small during low-velocity impact loading at room temperature conditions. Lesser and Filippov,11 experimentally examined the impact force–displacement response of a variety of (unspecified) quasi-isotropic composite laminates, and showed that load–displacement curves determined from quasi-static and low-velocity impact tests are similar. Of particular interest in damage tolerance assessment of composites is the quantification of the threshold force for damage initiation. Several studies, see Sjoblom and Hwang,12 indicate that damage is introduced when a discontinuity in the contact force response curve is observed. Typically, damage occurs in the form of matrix cracking, delamination and fiber failure; delamination is observed at several ply interfaces.13 Davis et al.13 examined both stress- and fracture-based criteria for delamination initiation and growth, and correlated the damage area to the impact force for a circular delamination in panels of various thicknesses. Davis et al.13 showed that there is a threshold force below which damage will not propagate. Lesser and Filipov11 and Abrate1 also used quasi-static tests to establish the threshold impact force below which an impact will not cause damage. Damage inspection of the quasi-static and low-velocity impact loaded panels loaded to comparable force magnitudes revealed similar types and size of damage. Experimental modal analysis of low-velocity impacted composite panels14 furthermore revealed that the shifts in the natural frequencies of higher order bending modes were small. These results indicate that the quasi-static loading approach seems reasonable for analysis of low-velocity impact loading of composite panels.

This study is focused on analysis and testing of the impact force response of two woven carbon vinylester composites which are candidate materials for Naval ship structures. The compression after impact of these composites was examined in a previous publication by the authors.15 Quasi-static testing is here conducted to determine the responses related to the indentation and global bending of these materials. Quasi-static loading past the linear elastic region will furthermore establish a threshold force beyond which damage occurs and the post-damage response of panels. Drop weight impact tests will be conducted at multiple drop heights to produce impact force versus velocity data. The contact law and bending stiffnesses determined using quasi-static testing will be used in a spring-mass model to analyze the magnitude of impact force.

sec.title: Hertzian contact model
sec.p:
The transfer of energy between the moving impact head and the composite panel occurs through physical contact between the two bodies. This results in local deformation at the impact site (indentation), and global bending deformation of the panel. Figure 1 schematically illustrates the displacement, δ1, of the contact point at the top surface of the impacted specimen, and the displacement of the corresponding point on the bottom surface, denoted by δ2. The thickness change, ‘indentation’, is given by (1)δin=δ2-δ1 Figure 1.
Schematic of indentation process during low-velocity impact loading.

The Hertzian contact between an elastic hemispherical object (striker) and elastic half-space (composite panel) is commonly employed to analyze the indentation response of composites. The Hertzian contact law is given by3 (2)F=kcδinn where F is the magnitude of the contact force, kc is the contact stiffness, and n is the exponent (power), which according to the original Hertzian analysis is, n=3/2, for a sphere contacting a flat infinite material (half-space). Willis4 considered a semi-infinite transversely isotopic material under loading by a rigid sphere and derived a contact law of the form as equation (2) with n=3/2. He also derived an equation for the contact stiffness, kc, (3)kc=43E3Rs where E3 is the transverse modulus of the composite and Rs is the radius of the indenter. Yang and Sun6 conducted indentation tests on carbon/epoxy and glass/epoxy composites and found n=3/2 for both composites

sec.title: Energy model
sec.p:
The principle of energy conservation can be used to estimate the magnitude of the impact force, Fi using a two-degree of freedom spring-mass-model.8 Greszczuk’s model assumes that the kinetic energy from the striker is fully transferred to the composite panel during the impact event and that the material is linearly elastic. Figure 2 shows the two-degree of freedom spring-mass model representative of the falling weight impact loading, with the striker, of mass, ms, falling from a height of h, and the indentation and panel stiffnesses represented by springs of stiffnesses kc and kp connected in series. Figure 2.
Spring-mass model for impact loading of a panel by a falling weight.

The mass of the panel, mp, is assumed to be negligible compared to the mass of the striker, ms, i.e., mp≪ms. This assumption means that inertia effects due to weight of the panel can be neglected. Also the contact duration is assumed to be much longer than the period of the fundamental mode of vibration. This could be a reasonable assumption for low-velocity impact loading which implies that the dynamic impact force will produce deflections (indentation and global bending) similar to those produced by a slowly (quasi-static) applied load. Elastic response of the panel is furthermore assumed.

Greszczuk] formulated the following energy balance for the spring-mass system (4)12msV02=12Fmax2kp+1n+1Fmax(n+1)/nkc1/n where Vo is the velocity of the falling weight at impact and Fmax is the peak impact force during the impact event. Equation (4) will be solved numerically to determine the peak magnitude of the impact force for a given velocity after determining the two spring constants (kp and kc) and the exponent, n, in the contact law.

sec.title: Materials and specimens
sec.p:
Composite panels utilizing carbon (C) fibers and vinylester (VE) resins are examined. The carbon fiber is a high strain (T700) fiber obtained from Toray coated with FOE sizing. This sizing is specially designed by Toray to provide compatibility with vinylester resins to enhance fiber/matrix interface adhesion. The fibers were arranged into a 2-D plain weave fabric with the same roving in the warp and weft directions. Two types of vinylester resins were used, namely, Derakane Vinylester 510A-40 (VE 510A) and Derakane Vinylester 8084 (VE 8084) provided by Ashland.16,17 The VE510A has good fire resistance but is relatively brittle, while the VE 8084 includes rubber particles suspended in the resin to promote ductility. Table 1 lists pertinent properties of the carbon fiber and vinylester resins used in this research. The subscripts ‘1’ and ‘2’ refer to the axial and radial directions of the fiber. The data was obtained from the resin manufacturer and literature.16–18 Table 1.
Fiber and resin mechanical properties.14–16
Property T700 Carbon fiber VE resins
510A 8084
E1 (GPa) 233 3.40 2.90
E2 = E3 (GPa) 15 3.40 2.90
ν12 0.2 0.35 0.35
G12 (GPa) 12 1.21 1.04
σult (MPa) 2450 86 76
εult (%) 1.7 4–5 8–10

Composite panels were manufactured from the plain weave fabric. Dry layers of fabric were placed alternated i.e. 0/90, 90/0, etc. in a total of 16 layers. After lay-up of the 16 plies, the fabric stack was enclosed by a vacuum bag and resin was injected to impregnate the fibers according to the VARTM process.19 The panels were cured at room temperature for a minimum of 24 h and post-cured at 80°C for 6 h. The panel thickness after cure was about 5 mm (Table 2). Rectangular, 152 mm × 102 mm, impact test specimens were cut using a diamond-coated water-cooled tile cutter. Table 2.
Quasi-static loading results
C/VE510A C/VE8084
Thickness (mm) 5.46 ± 0.15 5.63 ± 0.21
kp (MN/m) 2.81 ± 0.11 3.62 ± 0.61
kc (GN/mn) 1.14 ± 0.35 1.00 ± 0.24
n 1.39 ± 0.06 1.38 ± 0.09
F (threshold) (kN) 3.47 ± 0.34 4.02 ± 0.53

sec.title: Drop weight impact test machine
sec.p:
A drop weight impact test machine was designed and built according to the ASTM D 7136 standard20 described in more detail in Dale et al.15 Figure 3 shows a schematic of the impact test machine. The striker mass is about 7 kg. Drop heights from 0 to 0.75 m are possible. Based on the potential energy (mgh) this range of height corresponds to impact energies up to 51.6 J. The striker was made from hardened steel with a hemispherical front of radius 7.9 mm. The test specimen is supported by an aluminum fixture designed according to ASTM D713620 shown in Figure 4. This fixture consists of a 2.54 cm thick aluminum plate supported by 2.54 cm diameter solid aluminum rods connected to the corners of the plate. The impact test specimen is clamped over a rectangular hole of 7.6 cm × 12.7 cm using four rubber tipped toggle clamps (clamps are not shown in Figure 4). Also a position laser made by Micro-Epsilon (model optoNCDT 1300) was installed to record the incoming velocity. Figure 3.
Schematic of drop weight impact test setup. Figure 4.
Specimen support fixture for impact testing.

To record the impact force history a Dytran series 3086A/AT accelerometer was mounted on the cross head, directly above the striker. The accelerometer was powered by a calibrated current source. The signal from the accelerometer was recorded at 60 kHz using a breakout board attached to a computer. Once the signal was recorded it was filtered using an electronic tenth-order Butterworth low pass filter to eliminate the high frequency (ringing) component of the signal. Figure 5 shows examples of an unfiltered and filtered impact force signal to provide an indication of the extent of noise in the system. The higher frequency noise content is most likely due to reverberated waves bouncing back to the striker while it is in contact with the panel. There is some low frequency noise present that could not be removed. This noise was most likely caused by interference from other electronics in the vicinity of the test equipment. Figure 5.
Unfiltered and filtered accelerometer signals for low-velocity impact loading of a C/VE510A panel impacted at a height of 0.685 m.

Impact tests were performed on composite specimens over a range of drop heights. The purpose of this series of tests was to determine the magnitude of impact force experimentally and compare the results to predictions from the spring-mass model, equation (4). Three drop heights were selected: 10, 28, and 68.5 cm with five replicate specimens for each drop height. These drop heights correspond to impact energies (mgh) of 6.9, 19.2, and 47 J. Prior to the actual impact tests, a series of impact tests were performed on a dummy specimen at every 10 cm starting at 20 cm above the test specimen to determine the impact velocity.

sec.title: Quasi-static indentation test
sec.p:
Quasi-static impact tests were conducted on composite panels to determine the contact and bending stiffnesses kc and kp, damage threshold, and the post-damage response. The quasi-static test setup employed the same specimen support fixture and striker head as in the drop weight impact tester (Figures 3 and 4). The striker head was attached to a load cell connected to the moving cross head of a Tinius Olsen Universal testing machine. A ‘C’ bracket was constructed and attached to the striker so that the bottom of the bracket wraps around the specimen support plate (Figure 6). This arrangement is similar to the fixture Yang and Sun6 developed for monitoring indentation. A LVDT (#2) was attached to the bottom of the bracket to directly monitor the change in thickness (indentation), equation (1), during loading. The cross head displacement, δ, was measured with LVDT #1. This displacement represents the combined global and local displacement from which the bending displacement can be determined; however, it also includes the deformation of the load cell (δLC) as symbolized by the coil spring in Figure 6. Because the impact test specimen is stiff, it becomes necessary to compensate for displacement of the load cell (‘machine compliance’). Figure 6.
Fixture for determining indentation and bending response of test panel.

The machine compliance was measured by inserting a 76.2 mm thick hardened steel gage block on the support fixture and applying compression load using the same set-up as for the composite test panels. Load was applied very slowly and the load, P, and cross-head displacement, δ, were recorded. The gage block was assumed not to deform, so the displacement data recorded would just represent the response of the load cell (δLC). In an actual quasi-static test, the striker displacement, δ1, at any given applied load is the difference between the deformations of the cross-head and load cell (5)δ1=δ-δLC

When testing composite panels using the C-bracket fixture (Figure 6) the load and the displacements from the two LVDTs were monitored. The loading portion of a loading–unloading cycle was used to determine the contact rigidity kc and exponent, n, in equation (2). This is accomplished by constructing a log–log plot of the recorded load and indentation data. According to equation (2), this would yield a straight line. (6)logF=logkc+nlogδin
The stiffness, kc, is obtained from the intercept with the log F axis when logδin=0, and the exponent, n is the slope of the line.

The quasi-static test can also be used to determine the minimum load to initiate damage (threshold force). This is accomplished by constructing load versus bending deformation (δ2) graphs. The threshold is defined by the load where a deviation from the linear response occurs.

sec.title: Quasi-static indentation test results
sec.p:
The load–displacement (global) response of the composites during quasi-static loading was recorded. Figure 7 shows typical results for the two composites. The curve for the C/VE8084 panel displays a marked deviation from the initial linear response at a load of about 4 kN while the C/VE510A panel displays a knee-point followed by a close to linear response with reduced slope after the threshold at about 3.5 kN. The bending stiffness, kp, was determined from the slope of the initial linear region of the graph. Results are listed in Table 2. It is noted that the C/VE8084 panels are stiffer in bending than the C/VE510A panels. This could be attributed to the slightly larger thickness of the C/VE8084 panels (Table 2). Load–indentation data was collected from the measured load and displacement signals. Figure 8 shows the load–indentation response. It is noted that past the damage threshold, a stiffening effect is noted. This stiffening effect is due to the change in local contact stress distribution. Once the damage threshold is reached and damage begins to initiate, the material stiffness around the contact region decreases allowing ‘wrapping’ of the laminate over the indenter increasing the contact area. This increase in contact area causes a drop in the local contact stress resulting in the apparent stiffening. Similar results were reported by Wu et al.21 for a composite laminate loaded by a cylindrical indenter. Figure 7.
Load–deflection response during quasi-static testing. Figure 8.
Full load–indentation plots for C/VE510A and C/VE8084.

Figure 9 shows examples of log–log plots constructed according to equation (8) from load and indentation data below the damage threshold force collected from two C/VE510A and C/VE8084 panels. For both panels, the data form very close to linear relationships, in agreement with equation (6). Figure 10 shows experimental force–indentation data and response curves calculated from equation (2) using the reduced kc and n values. Very good agreement is noted. Figure 9.
Log–log plot of experimental indentation data. (a) C/VE510A and (b) C/VE8084. Figure 10.
Indentation responses for C/VE510A and C/VE8084. The discrete points represent measured data and the continuous curves the response calculated according to equation (2).

The contact stiffness, kc, and exponent, n, were reduced from Figure 9 and similar graphs constructed for all specimens tested. Average results are listed in Table 2. It can be observed that the contact stiffness, kc, for the indentation deformation is similar for both systems. The exponent n in the contact law is about n = 1.4, for both systems. This value falls slightly below the theoretical Hertzian contact value of n = 1.5 [3,4], and the value found experimentally by Yang and Sun (n = 1.5).6 Deviations could be due to the coarse weave structure and finite thicknesses of the test panels. Equation (3) was used to estimate the contact stiffness, kc, using the through-thickness modulus for a plain weave carbon/epoxy composite listed in Daniel and Ishai;18 E3 = 13.8 GPa, and the radius of the indenter, R = 7.9 mm which provides: kc=1.23 GPa1.5. Comparison with the experimental results for kc in Table 2 reveals that equation (3) reasonably predicts the contact stiffness.

The threshold force indicating the onset of damage formation was determined from the point on the load–displacement graph where the load–displacement curve deviates from linearity, see Figure 7. The threshold force for the C/VE510A composite is less than that for the C/VE8084 system. This could be due to the lesser ductility of the VE510A resin (see the strains to failure in tension listed in Table 1).

sec.title: Drop-weight impact force results
sec.p:
A series of drop tests were conducted to measure the impact velocity using the position laser at every 10 cm starting at 20 cm, 5 replicates were used at each drop height. The measured velocity was then plotted vs. the calculated free-fall velocity (Vf=2gh), Figure 11. The data was fitted to a linear equation with an y intercept equal to zero. The slope of the linear fit, c, is the ratio of actual velocity, Vo, to free-fall velocity. This slope was used as the calibration factor for determining an impact velocity at any given height, equation (7). (7)Vo=cVf Figure 11.
Calibration curve for impact velocity.

It was found that the actual impact velocity is lower than free-fall velocity by a factor of 0.87, Figure 11. The difference is attributed to friction in the linear bearings supporting the falling weight.

Composite panels were subject to different impact heights (10, 28, 68.5 cm). Typical filtered force traces for the C/VE510A and panels composites impacted at h = 68.5 cm are shown in Figure 12. The negative force readings before and after the impact force peak are due to low frequency noise in the signal. Such noise makes it difficult identifying the exact start and end points of the impact but is assumed that the impact begins and ends when the impact force is equal to zero. It is observed that irregular behavior is observed in the loading portion of both curves which indicates damage formation, although no drastic drops are noticed indicating limited damage progression, consistent with the quasi-static results shown in Figure 7. Notice that both systems experience peak impact forces close to 8 kN, well above the quasi-static damage formation thresholds listed in Table 2. Table 3 summarizes the measured magnitudes of impact force and the impact heights and velocities. The lowest drop height (10 cm) produces impact forces very close to the quasi-static damage initiation threshold for both composites (Table 2). Figure 12.
Impact force traces: (a) C/VE510A and (b) C/VE8084. Table 3.
Impact force magnitude at various drop heights
Drop height (cm) Impact velocity (m/s) Impact force (kN)
C/VE510A C/VE8084
10 1.22 3.78 ± 0.26 3.71 ± 0.23
28 2.04 5.64 ± 0.40 6.10 ± 0.76
68.5 3.19 8.16 ± 0.76 7.32 ± 0.83

To examine the validity of the dynamic mass-spring model discussed in the ‘Energy model’ section (equation (4)), the stiffnesses, kp and kc, listed in Table 2 were utilized in equation (4) together with the impact velocity, Vo obtained from equation (7). The calculated impact force is plotted vs. impact velocity for the two composites, Figure 13, which also shows the experimentally measured impact force data. The force prediction of the model used is strictly ‘valid’ only up to a force of approximately 3 kN, see Figure 8, which is the extent of the indentation data used to obtain the contact stiffness, kc. The impact model is in qualitative agreement with test results for the two composites, but underestimates the impact force. Jackson and Poe9 pointed out that if force prediction methods do not accommodate damage formed during impact loading, the force predictions will deviate from the experimentally measured ones because the material is no longer linearly elastic. If the material damage causes an apparent stiffening of the indentation response, Figure 8, the model will under predict the impact force. Jackson and Poe9 also noted that the energy solution using stiffnesses determined from quasi-static test procedures may under predict the impact force if the flexural waves of the impacted specimen do not have enough time to propagate and reflect during the impact event to produce the same mode of deformation as in the quasi-static testing. Damage inspection of the impacted panels15 revealed that impact loading of C/VE510A and C/VE8084 panels at a drop height of 68.5 cm produced localized damage near the impact site in the form of bundle cracking and delamination. Figure 13.
Measured and calculated impact force vs impact velocity for: (a) C/VE510A and (b) C/VE8084.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An experimental study on the impact force behavior of Naval composites subject to quasi-static and low-velocity impact loading has been conducted. Both composites utilized plain weave T700 carbon fibers in 8084 and 510A vinylester matrix resins. Quasi-static impact loading was conducted to establish the indentation and global bending stiffnesses of the panels. In addition, the threshold force for damage onset was determined using quasi-static loading. The C/VE510A systems displayed a lower impact force threshold for damage initiation than the C/VE8084 system, which is attributed to the 510A matrix being more brittle than the 8084. Drop-weight impact tests instrumented with an accelerometer and a displacement laser were conducted over a range of drop heights in order to collect impact force versus velocity data. The magnitude of impact force at a given drop height was similar for both systems. With the contact and bending stiffnesses determined from the quasi-static test, a spring-mass model was utilized to calculate the magnitude of impact force. The spring-mass model predictions of impact force magnitude were in reasonable agreement with experimental results, although the model tends to under-predict the force, except at the highest impact energy.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by ONR [grant number N00014-05-1-0341], managed by Dr Yapa Rajapakse.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The composite panels were manufactured at NAVSEA, Carderock, facilitated through Dr Roger Crane. Thanks go also to our machinist, Jeff Webb, for help with design and manufacture of the impact tester. We would also like to acknowledge the advice from Prof. C. T. Sun, Purdue University, in design of the impact tester.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
